files.README.md:
# StyleMate Plugin Marketplace

Official Claude Code plugin marketplace for the StyleMate microservices platform. This marketplace provides specialized agents, skills, and commands for building production-ready microservices with Module Federation, Clean Architecture, and JWT authentication.

## üì¶ Available Plugins

### stylemate-architecture

Complete development and QA workflow for StyleMate microservices with automated testing and validation.

**Version**: 1.0.0
**License**: MIT

#### What's Included

##### ü§ñ Development Agents (3)
- **work-planner-agent**: Decomposes business requirements into actionable tasks for React microfrontends, .NET APIs, Module Federation integration, and Docker orchestration
- **ui-engineer-agent**: Builds React 19 micro-frontends with Module Federation, Material-UI, and JWT authentication **(mandates QA validation)**
- **dotnet-engineer-agent**: Creates ASP.NET Core 8 microservices with Clean Architecture, EF Core, and JWT **(mandates QA validation)**

##### üß™ QA & Testing Agents (3)
- **qa-frontend-engineer**: Validates React UIs with Playwright MCP - tests functionality, responsiveness, accessibility, CRUD operations, and Module Federation
- **qa-backend-engineer**: Validates .NET APIs with curl - tests JWT auth, business isolation, CRUD endpoints, Clean Architecture compliance
- **context-manager**: Manages conversation context, tracks project state, provides relevant information to specialized agents

##### üéØ Architecture Skills (3)
- **module-federation-setup**: Set up Vite Module Federation with proper shared dependencies and route exposure
- **clean-architecture-validator**: Validate .NET API structure follows Clean Architecture with proper layer separation
- **jwt-integration**: Implement JWT authentication for both .NET APIs and React microfrontends

##### üî¨ Testing Skills (3)
- **playwright-e2e-testing**: Execute end-to-end testing of React microfrontends using Playwright MCP
- **api-integration-testing**: Test .NET API endpoints with curl to validate JWT, CRUD, and business isolation
- **build-and-lint-verification**: Verify code quality by running build and lint commands for .NET and React

##### ‚ö° Slash Commands (2)
- `/new-microservice`: Scaffold a complete microservice with .NET API and React UI
- `/validate-architecture`: Validate a microservice follows all StyleMate architectural standards

##### üîî Automation Hooks
- **PostToolUse hooks**: Notify when React/NET code modified, remind to run QA
- **SubagentStop hooks**: Trigger QA validation after development agents finish
- **UserPromptSubmit hooks**: Validate completion criteria before marking tasks done

## üöÄ Installation

### Prerequisites
- Claude Code installed and running
- Basic familiarity with the StyleMate platform architecture

### Install the Marketplace

#### Option 1: From Local Repository (Development)
```bash
# From your StyleMate project root
claude

# In Claude Code
/plugin marketplace add ./market-plugin
```

#### Option 2: From Git Repository (Production)
```bash
# In Claude Code
/plugin marketplace add https://github.com/your-org/stylemate-plugins
```

### Install the Plugin

After adding the marketplace:

```bash
# Interactive installation (recommended)
/plugin

# Select "Browse Plugins" ‚Üí "stylemate-architecture" ‚Üí "Install"

# Or install directly
/plugin install stylemate-architecture@stylemate-plugins
```

### Verify Installation

```bash
# Check available commands
/help

# Check available agents
/agents

# You should see:
# - /new-microservice command
# - /validate-architecture command
# - work-planner-agent
# - ui-engineer-agent
# - dotnet-engineer-agent
```

## üìñ Usage Guide

### Using Agents

Agents can be invoked explicitly or Claude will use them automatically when appropriate.

#### Explicit Invocation
```
Use the work-planner-agent to create a plan for a staff scheduling feature
```

#### Automatic Delegation
Claude automatically delegates to agents based on task context:
- Planning tasks ‚Üí work-planner-agent
- React/UI development ‚Üí ui-engineer-agent
- .NET API development ‚Üí dotnet-engineer-agent

### Using Skills

Skills are automatically invoked by Claude based on task context. You don't need to call them explicitly.

Examples of when skills activate:
- Setting up Module Federation ‚Üí module-federation-setup skill
- Validating project structure ‚Üí clean-architecture-validator skill
- Implementing JWT ‚Üí jwt-integration skill

### Automated QA Workflow

**CRITICAL**: All development agents automatically mandate QA validation. Work is NOT complete without QA approval.

#### Frontend QA Flow
```
1. ui-engineer-agent builds React components
2. Runs npm run lint
3. Runs npm run build
4. Automatically invokes qa-frontend-engineer
5. QA agent uses Playwright MCP to test:
   - Component functionality
   - CRUD operations
   - Mobile responsiveness
   - Form validation
   - Navigation
   - Console errors
6. QA reports pass/fail
7. If fail, fixes applied and re-tested
8. Only then is work marked complete
```

#### Backend QA Flow
```
1. dotnet-engineer-agent builds API endpoints
2. Runs dotnet build
3. Runs dotnet test
4. Automatically invokes qa-backend-engineer
5. QA agent uses curl to test:
   - JWT authentication (401 without token)
   - Authorization (403 for wrong role)
   - Business isolation (404 for other business)
   - CRUD operations
   - Input validation
   - Health checks
6. QA reports pass/fail
7. If fail, fixes applied and re-tested
8. Only then is work marked complete
```

### Using Commands

#### Create a New Microservice
```
/new-microservice

# Claude will prompt for:
# - Context name (e.g., "scheduling")
# - API port (e.g., 8003)
# - UI port (e.g., 3003)
# - Domain entities
# - User roles
```

#### Validate Architecture
```
/validate-architecture scheduling

# Generates comprehensive report checking:
# - Clean Architecture compliance
# - JWT authentication setup
# - Module Federation configuration
# - Docker setup
# - Integration with shell
```

## üèóÔ∏è Architecture Standards Enforced

### .NET API Standards
- **Clean Architecture** with Domain/Application/Infrastructure/Controllers layers
- **ASP.NET Core 8** with EF Core and PostgreSQL
- **JWT Authentication** with role-based authorization
- **Async/await** on all I/O operations
- **Business isolation** via JWT claims
- **Health checks** and monitoring
- **Docker** containerization

### React UI Standards
- **React 19** with TypeScript
- **Vite** with Module Federation plugin
- **Atomic Design** component structure (atoms ‚Üí molecules ‚Üí organisms ‚Üí pages)
- **Material-UI (MUI)** for consistent design
- **JWT integration** with Axios interceptors
- **Responsive design** mobile-first approach
- **Route guards** with authorization metadata
- **Docker** containerization with Nginx

### Infrastructure Standards
- **Nginx** reverse proxy configuration
- **Docker Compose** orchestration
- **Health checks** for all services
- **Security headers** (HSTS, CSP, X-Frame-Options)
- **stylemate_net** network for service communication

## üéì Examples

### Example 1: Complete Development Flow with QA

```
Step 1: Plan the Feature
--------
Use the work-planner-agent to plan a staff scheduling feature where
employees can view and update their schedules.

Step 2: Build the API
--------
Use the dotnet-engineer-agent to create the scheduling API with CRUD endpoints.

Result: API code created, dotnet build passes, dotnet test passes

Step 3: Mandatory QA - Backend
--------
dotnet-engineer-agent automatically invokes qa-backend-engineer agent.

QA tests:
‚úì dotnet build succeeds
‚úì JWT authentication required (401 without token)
‚úì Authorization enforced (403 for wrong role)
‚úì Business isolation works
‚úì CRUD endpoints return correct status codes
‚úì Health check responds 200

Result: All tests PASS - API approved

Step 4: Build the UI
--------
Use the ui-engineer-agent to create the schedule calendar page.

Result: React components created, npm run lint passes, npm run build succeeds

Step 5: Mandatory QA - Frontend
--------
ui-engineer-agent automatically invokes qa-frontend-engineer agent.

QA tests with Playwright:
‚úì Opens http://localhost:3003
‚úì Schedule calendar renders
‚úì Create schedule form works
‚úì New schedule appears immediately
‚úì Edit schedule saves changes
‚úì Delete schedule removes item
‚úì Mobile responsive (375px, 768px, 1200px)
‚úì No console errors

Result: All tests PASS - UI approved

Step 6: Mark Complete
--------
Work is now complete with QA validation. Ready to commit and deploy.
```

### Example 2: Create Scheduling Microservice

```bash
/new-microservice

Context name: scheduling
API port: 8003
UI port: 3003
Entities: Schedule, Shift, TimeOff
Roles: Owner, Admin, Manager, Staff

# Result: Complete microservice created with:
# - scheduling/scheduling-api (Clean Architecture .NET)
# - scheduling/scheduling-ui (React + Module Federation)
# - Docker configurations
# - JWT authentication
# - Nginx routing
```

### Example 2: Plan Feature with Work Planner

```
Use the work-planner-agent to plan a feature that allows staff members to view
and update their availability for scheduling. They should be able to set recurring
availability patterns and request time off.

# Result: Detailed plan with:
# - API tasks (endpoints, DTOs, database schema)
# - UI tasks (components, routes, state management)
# - Shell integration steps
# - Docker and Nginx updates
# - Security checklist
# - QA requirements
```

### Example 3: Validate Existing Service

```bash
/validate-architecture scheduling

# Result: Comprehensive report with:
# ‚úì Clean Architecture compliance
# ‚úó Missing [Authorize] on StaffController
# ‚ö† Warning: No index on ScheduleDate
# ‚úì Module Federation configured correctly
# ‚úó Missing health check in API
# + Recommended fixes
```

## üîß Configuration

### Team Setup

To automatically install plugins for your team, add to `.claude/settings.json`:

```json
{
  "pluginMarketplaces": [
    {
      "name": "stylemate-plugins",
      "source": "./market-plugin"
    }
  ],
  "plugins": {
    "stylemate-architecture": {
      "enabled": true,
      "autoInstall": true
    }
  }
}
```

### Customizing Agents

You can override plugin agents by creating project-level agents in `.claude/agents/` with the same name. Project-level agents take precedence.

## üìù Best Practices

### When to Use Each Agent

**work-planner-agent**: Use for:
- Breaking down new features into tasks
- Planning microservice architecture
- Creating comprehensive implementation plans
- Security and QA planning

**ui-engineer-agent**: Use for:
- Building React components
- Setting up Module Federation
- Implementing responsive designs
- JWT integration in frontend
- Creating route configurations

**dotnet-engineer-agent**: Use for:
- Building .NET APIs
- Implementing Clean Architecture
- Setting up EF Core and migrations
- Configuring JWT authentication
- Creating authorization policies

### Workflow Recommendations

1. **Start with Planning**: Use `/new-microservice` or work-planner-agent
2. **Build API First**: Let dotnet-engineer-agent create the backend
3. **Then Build UI**: Let ui-engineer-agent create the frontend
4. **Validate**: Run `/validate-architecture` before deployment
5. **Integrate**: Update shell application to consume the new remote

## üêõ Troubleshooting

### Plugin Not Loading
```bash
# Check installed plugins
/plugin

# Reinstall if needed
/plugin uninstall stylemate-architecture@stylemate-plugins
/plugin install stylemate-architecture@stylemate-plugins
```

### Agents Not Appearing
```bash
# Verify agents are available
/agents

# If missing, check plugin installation
/plugin
```

### Commands Not Working
```bash
# Verify commands are registered
/help

# Restart Claude Code if needed
exit
claude
```

## üìö Additional Resources

- [Claude Code Documentation](https://docs.claude.com/en/docs/claude-code)
- [Module Federation Guide](https://module-federation.io/)
- [Clean Architecture Principles](https://blog.cleancoder.com/uncle-bob/2012/08/13/the-clean-architecture.html)
- [JWT Best Practices](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc8725)

## ü§ù Contributing

To add new plugins to this marketplace:

1. Create plugin directory under `market-plugin/`
2. Add `.claude-plugin/plugin.json` manifest
3. Create agents/ skills/ commands/ as needed
4. Update `marketplace.json` with new plugin entry
5. Test locally before deploying

## üìÑ License

MIT License - see individual plugin directories for specific licenses.

## üîñ Version History

### 1.0.0 (2025-01-19)
- Initial release with complete development and QA workflow
- **7 specialized agents**: 3 development + 3 QA + 1 context manager
- **6 skills**: 3 architecture + 3 testing
- **2 slash commands**: scaffolding and validation
- **Automation hooks**: PostToolUse, SubagentStop, UserPromptSubmit
- **Mandatory QA validation**: All dev agents must invoke QA before completion
- **Playwright MCP integration**: Frontend E2E testing
- **API testing with curl**: Backend integration testing
- Full StyleMate microservices support
- Module Federation and Clean Architecture enforcement
- JWT authentication patterns

---

**Maintained by**: StyleMate Team
**Support**: Create an issue in the repository
**Documentation**: See individual plugin READMEs for detailed usage
files.stylemate-architecture/README.md:
# StyleMate Architecture Plugin

Comprehensive Claude Code plugin for building production-ready microservices in the StyleMate platform. Provides specialized agents, reusable skills, and automation commands for React microfrontends with Module Federation and .NET APIs with Clean Architecture.

## Features

### ü§ñ Specialized Agents

#### work-planner-agent
Decomposes business requirements into executable plans across frontend, backend, and infrastructure layers.

**Use for**:
- Planning new microservices
- Breaking down features into tasks
- Creating architectural blueprints
- Defining security and QA requirements

**Capabilities**:
- Epic decomposition with "THINK HARDER" methodology
- Task generation for UI, API, Shell, and Infrastructure
- Security and authorization planning
- Docker and Nginx configuration
- Definition of Done (DoD) creation

**Example**:
```
Use the work-planner-agent to plan a staff scheduling system where employees
can view their schedules, set availability, and request time off.
```

#### ui-engineer-agent
Builds React 19 microfrontends with Module Federation, Material-UI, and JWT authentication.

**Use for**:
- Creating React components following atomic design
- Setting up Module Federation
- Implementing responsive mobile-first designs
- Integrating JWT authentication in frontends
- Building route configurations with authorization

**Capabilities**:
- Atomic design component creation (atoms ‚Üí molecules ‚Üí organisms ‚Üí pages)
- Module Federation configuration
- MUI theme integration
- JWT Axios interceptor setup
- Route guard implementation
- Mobile-responsive layouts

**Example**:
```
Use the ui-engineer-agent to build the scheduling calendar page with week/month
views, shift creation, and employee filtering. It should work on mobile and desktop.
```

#### dotnet-engineer-agent
Creates ASP.NET Core 8 microservices with Clean Architecture, EF Core, and JWT.

**Use for**:
- Building .NET 8 APIs
- Implementing Clean Architecture
- Setting up EF Core with PostgreSQL
- Configuring JWT authentication and authorization
- Creating repository and service layers

**Capabilities**:
- Clean Architecture project structure (Domain/Application/Infrastructure/Controllers)
- JWT authentication with role-based policies
- EF Core configuration and migrations
- Business data isolation via JWT claims
- Health check implementation
- Docker containerization

**Example**:
```
Use the dotnet-engineer-agent to create the staff scheduling API with endpoints
for CRUD operations on schedules, shifts, and time-off requests.
```

### üéØ Agent Skills

Skills are automatically invoked by Claude based on task context. You don't need to explicitly call them.

#### module-federation-setup
Sets up Vite Module Federation for React microfrontends.

**Automatically activates when**:
- Creating new microfrontend projects
- Configuring federation.config.ts
- Setting up shared dependencies
- Exposing routes to shell application

**Provides**:
- Complete federation.config.ts with proper shared dependencies
- Vite configuration with proxy settings
- Route export setup with metadata
- Shell integration instructions

#### clean-architecture-validator
Validates .NET API projects follow Clean Architecture principles.

**Automatically activates when**:
- Reviewing .NET project structure
- Checking for architectural violations
- Validating layer dependencies
- Ensuring proper separation of concerns

**Validates**:
- Domain layer has no dependencies
- Application depends only on Domain
- Infrastructure implements interfaces
- Controllers orchestrate workflows
- No circular dependencies

#### jwt-integration
Implements JWT authentication for both .NET and React.

**Automatically activates when**:
- Setting up authentication
- Configuring authorization policies
- Implementing token interceptors
- Adding route guards

**Provides**:
- .NET JWT validation configuration
- Authorization policy definitions
- React Axios interceptor setup
- Token refresh logic
- Route guard implementation

### ‚ö° Slash Commands

#### /new-microservice
Scaffolds a complete new microservice with all required components.

**Creates**:
- .NET API with Clean Architecture
- React UI with Module Federation
- Docker configurations
- Nginx routing
- JWT authentication setup
- Database migrations

**Prompts for**:
- Context name
- API and UI ports
- Domain entities
- User roles

**Example**:
```
/new-microservice

Context: scheduling
API Port: 8003
UI Port: 3003
Entities: Schedule, Shift, TimeOff
Roles: Owner, Admin, Manager, Staff
```

#### /validate-architecture
Performs comprehensive architectural validation of a microservice.

**Checks**:
- Clean Architecture compliance
- JWT authentication setup
- Module Federation configuration
- Docker and health checks
- Business data isolation
- Security headers
- Integration with shell

**Generates**:
- Detailed validation report
- Pass/fail/warning status for each check
- Specific line numbers for issues
- Recommended fixes

**Example**:
```
/validate-architecture scheduling

# Optional: Auto-fix common issues
/validate-architecture scheduling --fix
```

## Installation

### From StyleMate Project
```bash
# Start Claude Code
claude

# Add marketplace
/plugin marketplace add ./market-plugin

# Install plugin
/plugin install stylemate-architecture@stylemate-plugins
```

### Verify Installation
```bash
# Check agents
/agents

# Should show:
# - work-planner-agent
# - ui-engineer-agent
# - dotnet-engineer-agent

# Check commands
/help

# Should show:
# - /new-microservice
# - /validate-architecture
```

## Usage Examples

### Example 1: Plan and Build New Feature

```
Step 1: Plan the feature
--------
Use the work-planner-agent to plan a feature where managers can create and assign
shifts to employees. Employees should see their assigned shifts in a calendar view.

Step 2: Build the API
--------
Use the dotnet-engineer-agent to implement the Shift entity and CRUD endpoints.
Only Managers and Admins should be able to create/edit shifts.

Step 3: Build the UI
--------
Use the ui-engineer-agent to create the shift calendar component with week and
month views. It should be responsive for mobile and desktop.

Step 4: Validate
--------
/validate-architecture scheduling
```

### Example 2: Scaffold New Microservice

```bash
# Create complete microservice structure
/new-microservice

# Follow prompts to configure:
# - Context name: inventory
# - Entities: Product, Category, Supplier
# - Roles: Owner, Admin, Manager
# - Ports: API 8004, UI 3004

# Result: Complete microservice ready for development
```

### Example 3: Validate Existing Service

```bash
# Run comprehensive validation
/validate-architecture staff

# Review report:
# ‚úì Clean Architecture: Passed
# ‚úó JWT Authorization: Failed (missing [Authorize] on line 42)
# ‚ö† Module Federation: Warning (update react-router-dom to singleton)
# ‚úì Docker: Passed

# Apply auto-fixes
/validate-architecture staff --fix
```

## Architecture Patterns Enforced

### Clean Architecture (.NET)
```
Domain/          # Business entities and interfaces (no dependencies)
Application/     # Business logic and DTOs (depends on Domain)
Infrastructure/  # Data access and external services (implements interfaces)
Controllers/     # API orchestration (depends on all layers)
```

### Atomic Design (React)
```
atoms/        # Basic UI elements (Button, Input, Label)
molecules/    # Simple composites (SearchBox, FormField)
organisms/    # Complex components (DataTable, Modal, Header)
pages/        # Complete pages (Dashboard, ScheduleView)
```

### Module Federation
```typescript
// Exposes routes for consumption by shell
exposes: {
  './routes': './src/app/routes.tsx'
}

// Shares dependencies as singletons
shared: {
  'react': { singleton: true },
  'react-dom': { singleton: true },
  '@mui/material': { singleton: true }
}
```

### JWT Authentication
```csharp
// .NET Authorization Policies
"RequireOwnerOrAdmin": roles = ["Owner", "Admin"]
"RequireManagerOrAbove": roles = ["Owner", "Admin", "Manager"]
"RequireStaffAccess": roles = ["Owner", "Admin", "Manager", "Staff"]
"RequireBusiness": claim = "business_id"
```

```typescript
// React Route Metadata
meta: {
  label: "Schedules",
  allowedRoles: ["Owner", "Admin", "Manager"],
  requireEmailConfirmed: true,
  requireBusiness: true
}
```

## Configuration

### Required Environment Variables
```env
# JWT Configuration
JWT_ISSUER=stylemate-auth
JWT_AUDIENCE=stylemate-services
JWT_SECRET_KEY=your-secret-key-here

# Database
POSTGRES_DB=stylemate
POSTGRES_USER=postgres
POSTGRES_PASSWORD=postgres123

# Network
DOCKER_NETWORK=stylemate_net
```

### Nginx Routing Pattern
```nginx
# UI Remote
location /remotes/{context}-ui/ {
    proxy_pass http://{context}_ui:80/;
}

# API Endpoints
location /api/{context}/ {
    proxy_pass http://{context}_api:80/api/{context}/;
}
```

## Best Practices

### Agent Selection
- **Planning phase**: work-planner-agent
- **React development**: ui-engineer-agent
- **API development**: dotnet-engineer-agent

### Development Workflow
1. Plan with work-planner-agent
2. Build API with dotnet-engineer-agent
3. Build UI with ui-engineer-agent
4. Validate with /validate-architecture
5. Test with Docker Compose
6. Integrate with shell application

### Code Quality
- Always run `npm run lint` after UI changes
- Always run `dotnet build` after API changes
- Use Playwright testing for UI validation
- Write integration tests for APIs
- Validate architecture before deployment

## Troubleshooting

### Agent Not Available
```bash
# Check installation
/plugin

# Reinstall if needed
/plugin install stylemate-architecture@stylemate-plugins
```

### Skill Not Activating
Skills activate automatically. If you think a skill should have activated but didn't:
- Describe the task more explicitly
- Mention the specific technology (e.g., "Module Federation", "Clean Architecture")

### Command Not Found
```bash
# Verify commands are loaded
/help

# Restart Claude Code if needed
exit
claude
```

## Version History

### 1.0.0 (2025-01-19)
- Initial release
- 3 specialized agents (work-planner, ui-engineer, dotnet-engineer)
- 3 skills (module-federation-setup, clean-architecture-validator, jwt-integration)
- 2 commands (/new-microservice, /validate-architecture)

## License

MIT

## Support

For issues and questions:
- Review this documentation
- Check the main marketplace README
- Consult StyleMate platform documentation (CLAUDE.md)

plugins.name: stylemate-architecture
plugins.description: Complete development and QA workflow for StyleMate microservices. Includes 7 specialized agents (planning, frontend/backend development, frontend/backend QA, context management), 6 skills (Module Federation, Clean Architecture, JWT, E2E testing, API testing, build verification), 2 commands, and automatic validation hooks.
